Early Access Review
								Short version:Buy it if you prefer road racing sims to the more casual driving/racing games. Otherwise it's probably not for you. Also, no ovals currently.Long version:GeneralI'm no native Engish speaker. Automobilista (AMS) is Early Acces, but currently there is no racing sim that could be called a final product. So be aware that AMS and all the similar games are constantly changed, sometimes even introducing new bugs. I'm playing the game for quite a while, way before it came to Steam. The game is made by a small team and it seems that it's more about passion, than big money. It's not about being flashy, stylish etc., but about actual regulated car racing. No offense for NFS players, but this is the other end of the spectrum. It is true that AMS is based on rFactor 1, but it is much more than that.ContentThe game is rather obscure in this regard, but I personally like their picks. It started as a Brazilian Stock Car (which is a real thing) game, so the older content is Brazilian V8s and mostly Brazilian tracks. Over time they ventured into some popular and some less so areas, but most of the cars are quite different from each other. Many current games offer street cars, hypercars, GT3 and touring cars. AMS has Brazilian stock cars (60s, 80s and current), open wheel (old and new), fwd, rallycross, super trucks, and some more. Content is by no means mainstream. I didn't play much open wheel, but generally the cars feel authentic. I don't have any racing experience, but I'm driving probably before most Steam users were born. So yea, the cars feel really different. You sure don't drive the same a Formula Extreme and a Formula Vee. Night racing is supported, but no rain. Dynamic rubbering is on a Todo I think.Force FeedbackI have a Thrustmaster T500 + TH8 H shifter, so your experience may vary, depending on the wheel you use. This may be the best part of the game. I have all the actual racing sims and my personal experience is that no current game feels near to AMS regarding FFB, especially the later builds. This may be subjective experience, but it seems that the bigger the publisher, the worse the FFB gets (kudos to Codies/Dirt Rally, which is a rare exception). If you have driving experience, in AMS you can actually feel what is happening with the car (Neils' magic). Some of the more popular titles (that I'm playing too) are laughable in this area.AIDon't expect human behavior (carnage in T1), but racing with this AI is probably the most you can get if you play no MP. In most current sims, AI is questionable and this one is I had the most human-like races with. Be honest, even in the better ones, the first two laps are miserable. Here you see cars passing each other, passing you. On the other side, I didn't see any human-like mistakes (which I only saw in R3E). I've also been ocassionally divebombed, but no crazy AI flying all over the road or all AI pulled on a string.SPThe usual stuff. Training, race weekends and less usual, championships. There is no GT/AC/pCars like career. Championships are premade seasons for a car type. It is generally the same as rFactor1, except that the devs sometimes mess with the files and the championships don't really work, which is one of my main gripes with the game. For example in the current build, there are wrong (old) track names in the files and some series have 0 scoring. So without basic IT skills, you're doomed to wait for the devs.MPI only play that other game if I want actual MP racing without carnage, so I can't comment on this.VisualsDespite recently upgraded, visuals are a weak point. If you don't care about heat haze and sunrays, you'll be fine. But an AMS screenshot is like a photo of England on a regular day. SoundI find it that sound can get really subjective. I'm fine with sound in most racing sims.ConclusionMore for people who appriciate the older racing sims (GTR2, GTL, GPL etc) than posting a screenshot of your purple Huayra.PS I avoided mentionning other racing games where possible to avoid fanboys which unfortunately are a big chunk of racing sims/games communities.

												In my view, AMS is built around a very sharp observation. Around the year 2016, if you want a full suite racing simulator, you won't find one. One title offers superior visuals, but lacks some basic features even after years of development (Assetto Corsa). Other is packed with all the simulation features you want, gives you the best physics out there, but because of a lack of content and the somewhat last gen feel graphics, feels incomplete (rFactor2). The third teases you with officially licenced series, mindblowing sounds and attractive visuals, but again, fails in the features department, not to talk about robbing you with the plethora of microtransactions (RaceRoom Racing).Simply put, AMS is the only complete package out there. Although many say it is based on rFactor 1 engine, if the car feels as good as it does in AMS, I don't care what is there under the hood. Besides the excellent physics and FFB, the visual side is also top-notch. I don't know what the magic there is, but it simply looks and feels great, better than rF2. I especially like the day-night transitions, which are seamless, and the night racing experience is probably the best you can get. If that's not enough, all the features you liked in the previous generation of sims (you remember, back in the time when there was this strange habit of publishing finished products) - finally, they are there. And a big plus is that the game offers complete series, and though I was initially full of doubts as to how interesting these series can be for me, the European simracer, it was a very positive disappointment concerning both the cars and the tracks. The range of vehicles is vast, and even me, who is not a rally guy at all, find myself driving the Lancer RX simply because it is so much fun to drive.I had many doubts, but AMS totally convinced me - it is possibly the best, but most certainly the most complete sim you will get. The only negative in my view, is the price tag, but for the same array of content you could easily spend 60-70 EUR in some other titles, so maybe that's fair enough.

												Tons of variety with a satisfying feel!DISCLAIMER: Just a heads up that my review is coming from a racing sim noob with a Logitech G27 Racing Wheel plugged in a "toaster". I only play offline as well. So the pros, gear snobs, sim veterans, and club racers won't find much useful information within. And probably already have a heavy opinion anyway. I will try to gear this review towards the uninitiated and curious sim noobs like myself that are stumbling about Steam reviews behind the cheap steering wheel with genuine curiosity of whats out there. I had a very positive "Early Access" review of this title up, something I wouldn't normally do. The game was more or less feature complete though. And I gushed and fawned over the game like an eager fanboy with a new shiny toy. I've learned a thing or two along the way since and ratcheted things down a bit. But honestly, the shine hasn't worn off. 90hrs (plus more in the beta branch) of driving, crashing, learning, and even occasionally actually racing all by myself and I haven't even scuffed the sheen a bit. Its always a blast when you're on the road and even sometimes off it. Starting with the obvious; Variety is the spice of life and Automobilista delivers that in full. I can race in an open-wheeler that I prefer on a major track I love and know like the back of my hand... Or I can take an unwieldy Super Truck I can't handle on a track I've never heard of. Karts, Super V8's, formulas of every era, Caterhams, Camaros, Lancers, and much more. With more coming still! Each vehicle series looks, handles, and feel superb AND wholly unique. The track variety contains some classics as well as the obscure. They're all worth the time to learn and race. And the user made mods have been rolling out steadily since Early Access and only add more variety and options (HUDs/tracks/cars/skins/etc). But the real feature(s) that made it all worth it for me was the accessibility. I got my wheel for much tamer and/or "arcade-y" racing games. Then I ended up playing casual "sims" with it, towing trailers across Europe and logs through the mud in Russia. But when it came time to step up and strap in to a cockpit of something serious to really feel my toy wheel I ran into walls and dead ends at every turn. "True sim" racing is a niche if there ever was such a thing. An odd one with unique folks owning a wealth of information scattered wide and far. And with even more varying steadfast opinions filling each and every gap between. I poured hours into trying this sim or that sim. Reading webpages, blogs, and forums. Calibrating software, looking up force feedback settings, learning new terms, fiddling with in-game settings, trying to make old games work on new operating systems. And I always ended up with something that barely worked and left me thinking I was missing something. With Automobilista I read one thing, the included manual, and set things as suggested. Within minutes I was racing. And for the first time I FELT it. I felt what seduces souls the world over and turns them into sim racing fanatics. Force feedback and simulating physics is an amazing thing. Automobilista just works (granted you read a manual) and allowed me to finally start learning how to race and actually play a game rather than just how to configure things. Though, since it indeed "just worked" it did also let me learn how to configure things and know what settings should do and let me return to previous failures and succeed in trying things. In basic terms Automobilista starts you at step "1" and it sure is easier to start at step "1" instead of step "35", or "-35"!There's plenty of other subjective stuff I could go on about like how I do think its the best feeling sim out there and technical this or tire model that or how I like the visuals plenty fine. But the subjective opinion I will stand by the most is that this is the most approachable sim for the new guy/gal. That's not to say your journey will be as smooth as mine or it doesn't take some reading or work. And no promises you'll be any good. As with anything you're gonna get out what you put in with sim racing. My hours spent learning and configuring other games and scouring the web was never wasted, it just wasn't rewarded or fulfilling until it culminated in Automobilista. But knowledge is your friend in this niche. Learn and study anything you can get your hands on and just remember most of it is subjective in the end. The world doesn't need another steadfast stone that won't flex on anything. Find what you like and what works for you and know others should do the same. But if you got a wheel (and make no mistake a wheel is highly recommended if not flat out required) and you want to see what the hubbub is all about with sim racing without subscriptions or anything wacky, I can confidently suggest Automobilista is a good bet. Very much recommended!

ry 24
												Try the 1975 F1 car, called 'Formula Retro'.Try the 'Test day'.Pick you car and pick 'Johannesburg' as your track. This was the old Kyalami race circuit.Remove the 'Electronic aids' listed in the garage, and do so again in the 'Options' menu.Reduce the tyre pressures to 17.8 for the front, and 18.3 for the rear.Alter the camber to '0'.Now go and drive...Remember, the tyres are cold for the first lap, so don't push too hard yet.Hopefully you'll be getting a 'feel' for the car, and it should bring a smile to your face...After a while, you may feel confident enough to post a time on the 'Time trial', and you'll soon realise how much you want to do better...  ...and you get another go in 1m 13 seconds or so! Exhilarating isn't the word!Once I'd realised where all the 'Electronic aids' were in the menus, and removed them, I began to live.Even some time in the tardy Formula Vee helped my understanding of weight transfer.It's easy to over drive the car, and you need to control yourself to get the best out of it. And then there's the circuits...OLD Interlagos, with its fearsome double-apex first corner. I was taking the first part at 163mph! It takes your breath away.At Brasilia you'll begin to learn how to deal with the lack of grip. At Cascavel you'll have yor breath taken away again.The first corner is a full 180 degrees in fifth gear, ultimately leading into a VERY fast 4th gear left hander before you have to anchor it for a slow right. It's awesome!At Kansai, which is in fact Suzuka, you will be seriously challenged by the lack of grip. It's literally rally-driving a F1 car!Imagine taking a car like this to Britain's Cadwell park? It's a motorcycle track after all.Imagine no longer! Hanging on to this car at Cadwell requires your bravery as well as your judgement.Then you watch the replay and think, "Wow, this is also fantastic to watch!"Having played 'Grand Prix Legends' in the past, now being able to drive the Brabham is fantastic, nothing less.My frustrations are with the dreaded 'understeer' on everything, but it's easily controllable on the Brabham 'Formula retro', but I'm trying to engineer it out, which is quite a challenge.Having learned some set-up lessons from the Formula Retro, hopefully I can apply them to the other cars should I choose to try them.The graphics are fine by me, and anyway, it's the feel of the car that matters.I use a cheap Thrustmaster (Non-force feedback) steering wheel, which works very well.I'm really pleased with this game. It's frustrating but very rewarding trying really hard to get the best out of that old Brabham.

								My experience... I have been driving Grand Prix Legends since it was released in 1998. I have tried iRacing, fFactor 2, and Assetto Corsa. In my opinion Automobilista is a more realistic driving experience than all of them. From my first session on track I was convinced. Now that I've spent some more time dialing things in, I'm hooked. When you first start out, be sure to take the time to peruse the "user guide". The physics and ffb had me convinced immediately but the graphics were washed out. After reading the "user guide" on configuring Nvidia/ATI graphics cards and applying the recommended settings, the graphics are very good. The ffb is the best I have experienced. I'm still using my old faithful Logitech Momo Red wheel and an even older, modded, set of Thrustmaster pedals with a Flexiforce load sensor on the brake. I was going to test drive Project Cars but there's no need. I am quite happy with Automobilista. I would recommend Automobilista to anyone who is looking for a sim with realistic handling and feedback. If you are looking for more of an arcade experience, there is nothing to see here.Some thoughts on:iRacing... I quite liked iRacing but for me the ffb was not very good. A bit like driving underwater. I tried different settings but never found anything I was satisfied with. That said; I would stay with iRacing just for the sheer number of online races that are available, except for the cost. Ongoing subscription and then track and car purchases to move up the ranks are too much for me.rfactor 2... Great graphics but physics and ffb just seem unrealistic to me.Assetto Corsa... 								VIDEO AVAILABLE AT www.twitch.tv/ramalls.  WOW!  All I can say is ............. WOW!  iRacing, watch out.  This game currently cost 30 bucks with no residual cost (as of this writing).  Let's talk racing simulation.  1. Car physics.  Automobilista has nailed it!  The different cars have different physics and handling characteristics that you can feel!  Tire wear, suspension travel, brakes, camber.....you make adjustments and you feel the difference.  2. Dynamic tracks and tire wear. I swear while I was racing in the F3 car I could see my tires degrading over time............not just feel it but see it.  Now, maybe it's just because you have real time telemetry data that tells you what your tire state is, but I kept looking at my right front tire and I could swear I started seeing tread wear. Anyway, they have their tire model spot on.........and it's only going to get better.  The tires pick up gravel and grass if you run off the road and you can hear it on the pavement also.  Run behind someone that has ran off the road and hear the dirt and gravel ping and pong off your car's underbelly.  Great job.  3.  Force Feedback.  THIS RIGHT HERE PEOPLE IS WHAT FORCE FEEDBACK IS ALL ABOUT.  They got it right..........on the first try none the less.  There are a number of default setups for almost every racing wheel you can think of.  G27, G29, MoMo, driving force..........if you have a wheel, it's probably supported here.  (CAUTION:  This is a TRUE racing sim, so please don't attempt to drive with a gamepad.  I see some support is in there, but you really are not going to get the full experience).  4.  Graphics.  This is where some pundants say that Automobilista is failing.  I say that they are a small team of developers with a small budget that have created a simulation that is DIRECTLY  challenging Assetto Corsa, iRacing, RFactor, etc.  If I was to put the graphics to a scale of 1-10, I'd give them a solid 7.............but remember, this is an Early Access of the game.  How may of you remember Assetto Corsa's early access. Pretty damn strong graphics........horrible physics.  Automobilista is headed in the right direction.  5.  AI.  I know, I know...........who wants AI in a simulation racer.  Let's be honest, there isn't a racing sim out there that can compete with the online community of iRacing.  You ALWAYS find human racers to compete with.  That's not to say that Automobilista doesn't have a mulitplayer community.  Indeed, you can log on and find some multiplayer races.  However, the community has not expanded yet.  Therefore, you NEED AI to get some traffice time it.  The scaleable AI here is some of the best I've seen in a racing sim yet.  They truly try to find the best path around you for a pass and seem to attempt to avoid all contact.  5.  Complaints. As I said earlier, this is an early access of the game.  However, I want to be sure to let everyone know if some of the downsides that I think exists.  First, you will notice some clipping when you collide with certain artifacts in the game.  It's nothing that ruins the overall realism and fun of the sim, however, it's there. Also, there seems to be some scaling issues with a few of the tracks. Montreal's straights seem to be pretty short.  Speaking of tracks, there are curently 0 American Road  Courses in the game.  Hopefully this will change..........(Long Beach, St Petersburg......FORGET Laguna Seca).  There are also a lot of tracks that are either new to me or not real world tracks.  When setting up a single player practice session, you have to manually add the AI cars..............ONE CAR AT A TIME.....CLICK.....CLICK.....CLICK.... Hopefully this will get changed.  6.  Speaking of cars............There are several in here that are not mainstream to your typcial racer.  COPA is something complete new to me.............and I love it.  COPA MONTANA are GT trucks that are pretty damn fun to drive.  The other COPA (sorry cannot remember the spelling or name) is GT Hondas Civics and Cheverolets.  Pretty damn fun to run these rice burners.  There are also SUPER V8 TRUCKS and tracks (imaging dirt rally truck on a race track with buitl in jumps).  Definitely a change of pace.  What doesn't exist right now are true GT3/GT1 cars.  All in all, I'm really excited to see what Reiza is going to do with this simulation.  They have definitely come out swinging and are directly challenging the mainstream racing simulations on the market today.  This is how you do an early access game here........(hint hint hiht Star Citizen).  Looking forward to more to come.  I'll update this review as new content comes out.  See you on the track!!Oh, if you want to see video, check out my twitch page at http://www.twitch.tv/ramalls   Enjoy.

												Not without its flaws but a step-up (in terms of physics and immersion) from the likes of the GT franchise.Pros:- no grinding for credits as all cars and tracks are available from the off- great handling- dynamic track conditions (including evolving racing lines)- dynamic tyres (including visible dirt pick-up)- nice sounding cars- decent range of cars/series to choose from (several eras of F1 cars through Super V8s and the Marcas series)- competitive AI, which also makes the odd error from time-to-time- growing Mod library- great service from the devs who take the time to listen to the opinions of the community and even integrate some of the suggestions- customisable DynHUD (using DynHUD editor)- probably the most authentic sim racing experience outside of iRacingCons:- somewhat tame AI (in terms of AI-on-AI action) means its usually a case of simply 'follow the leader'- lack of both an introductory 'training school' feature and a Career Mode- no hover tips for the menu options (some of which may not be self-explanatory to the non-hardcore sim racer)- lack of more popular tracks as stock content (such as Spa, Nordschleife, Zaandvoort, etc.)- a somewhat small (though growing) online multiplayer community- essentially, just a rehash of rFactor (although this does show how talented the devs are, given the game engine is about 15 years old)To get a feel of what Reiza can do, try their totally free offering (Copa Petrobras de Marcas) first. If this impresses you (as it did me) then you'll get along with AMS just fine. The lack of more popular tracks may put some off making the investment, but there are quite a few Modders out there who have added a decent amount of additional content, which is still growing thanks to some good work from dedicated (and generous) enthusiast-level fans of the game.In my opinion, AMS is a stepping stone to bigger things. It's enjoyable as a sim in its own right, no doubt, but it's more a precursor to what I see as being Reiza's main project, which I understand will get underway in 2017. This I look forward to very much. For now, though, AMS will do just fine.As a side note, it's probably worth getting the season pass (especially if you can get it at a discounted price) because there are quite a few more DLC packs on the horizon, all of which (so far at least) seem to me to be worth making the investment.

								As everyone else is saying: the ffb and physics on this game are THE NEXT LEVEL. Combined with the force feedback and handling of the cars is the sense of speed delivered in the way you're virtual head moves about inside the cockpit. I set the head motion and yaw exaggeration to the maximum, cranked up "look ahead" all the way, and it REALLY adds to the sense of g forces involved in cornering, accelerating and braking inside the cockpit as it feels like the car is violently bucking and surging, as it should in an F1 car.As far as graphics go I was about to delete the game from my system and go on a forum and ♥♥♥♥♥ about how crappy they are until I discovered that you have to DISABLE SweetFX in the initial setup screen of the game, keep Anti Aliasing OFF...and then go into the nvidia control panel and manually setup the Anti Aliasing there to OVERRIDE the game's settings. I bumped my Anti Aliasing up to 32 supersample and now the graphics are smooth as silk. If you just install the game as is with sweetFX enabled the graphics look a bit like playstation 1, so don't delete it from you system until you follow the above.Don't expect Assetto Corsa level graphics here but to me, it's all about the smoothness of the jaggies. The textures of the track are done quite nicely and are very detailed. The cars are modeled very well but there are a few bugs in some views, such as when looking to the rear while in the cockpit your back wheels won't be visible in the F1 car. But this is still pre launch so I'm sure it will get fixed. The terrain in general is a bit bland but on par. The thing I'm finding with the tracks is they are all a little bland just by their nature, but a blast to drive. 												I was going to delete my old review, but then thought it would actually be best to leave it up, because I don’t think my experience with this title is unique. In short, my initial impressions of the AMS were observationally correct, and yet simultaneously completely…utterly…wrong. You can read the original review below this one. After doing a little reading, I decided to reinstall the game and give it another go last week. This time, armed with a little pre-knowledge and a more realistic expectation of the setup curve, my experience was completely different. First, the force feedback. I own and play (PCars, AC, R3E, and rF2) and IMO, with a little bit of tweaking, AMS has arguably some of the best force feedback I’ve ever felt in a sim.  And by a little bit of tweaking, I mean simply adjusting one setting in the .ini file to dial out any clipping from the default settings. A small bit of clipping is perfectly okay, but the devs claim the defaults settings, allow about 20-30% clipping. Not sure what wheel they tested that on, but on my CSW-V2, the default gain setting for the cars in the base installation allows a little too much clipping in the high-speed corners for my tastes. Not a big deal, very easy to dial out. And once you do, the cars will feel amazing. :)Second, the graphics. This was a big turn off for me the first time I tried AMS. Yes, I realize graphics aren’t the end-all-be-all measure for sim titles, but, coupled with what I thought at the time was poor FFB and a poorly designed GUI, the outdated looking graphics made me feel as though it wasn’t worth the time to negotiate the setup curve of the title. What I didn’t realize at the time was, AMS’ built-in graphics processing is terrible, but you don’t have to use it. By turning off almost every in-game graphic setting, and simply creating a profile in my GPU driver for AMS, and allowing the GPU to handle most of the processing, I was able to use the enhanced HDR setting in AMS, and it looks like a totally different game—very much comparable to any other modern title. When properly configured through the GPU, the outdated graphics gripe basically becomes a complete non-issue. Third, the GUI. Yes, it appears a bit cluttered and hard to navigate, but the more time I spend with the title, the more I seem to be discovering the method behind the madness. AMS remembers the little things, like which track you were driving in each particular car and what difficulty level you were using with that particular car/track combo. The latter was a welcome surprise, considering AI difficulty often varies by car/track combo. I believe some of these little conveniences that have been revealing themselves are made possible, in part, if not completely, by the way things are broken down and organized in the GUI. And, to be honest, after a few days of play, the GUI doesn’t seem nearly as chaotic as it did on day-one. :)So, as much as I’d like to say, “Please ignore my previous review.” I think reading them both is best, because there’s a good chance you’re going to be feeling some, if not all, of the things I felt about the game when I first tried it a few months ago. The thing to remember is, while all my past observations were indeed true, they only apply to the out-of-the box installation. With a little patience—a browse through the community forum and possibly a Google search or two—the initial installation can be transformed into a real racing pleasure that should appeal to just about any sim fan. Verdict: AMS is a definite must have for sim fans. Below is my original review. :o--------------------------------------------I heard a lot about this game and was excited about the track evolution aspect. After downloading it, and selecting the No Assist option, I then spent about 20 minutes trying to find out why it was still auto upshifting for me. After a Google search, I discovered that selecting manual wasn't enough (WTH??). There was a second setting for upshifting. Whatever, I moved on and started tackling the FFB. It felt promising, but when I went to start dialing it in, I realized there was no FFB meter (again... WTH?). I found a lot of information online, telling me to make manually adjustments in the config .ini files. That seemed a little archaic, and coupled with the lack of an FFB meter, I was just really turned off at this point. To make matters worse, the graphics are very, VERY dated looking, compared to just about any racing game made within the past 7 years. I have a GTX 1080 and had the settings cranked, viewing it on a 4K screen. It still looked dated. Even the onscreen HUD overlays looked like they were made for a kid's game. At the 1.5 hour mark, I just gave up an returned it. If I didn't already have three sims that I was thoroughly enjoying, I might have spent more time trying to massage AMS into shape. But there just seemed to be too much blind fiddling required. Verdict: Refunded.

												I was going to delete my old review, but then thought it would actually be best to leave it up, because I don’t think my experience with this title is unique. In short, my initial impressions of the AMS were observationally correct, and yet simultaneously completely…utterly…wrong. You can read the original review below this one. After doing a little reading, I decided to reinstall the game and give it another go last week. This time, armed with a little pre-knowledge and a more realistic expectation of the setup curve, my experience was completely different. First, the force feedback. I own and play (PCars, AC, R3E, and rF2) and IMO, with a little bit of tweaking, AMS has arguably some of the best force feedback I’ve ever felt in a sim.  And by a little bit of tweaking, I mean simply adjusting one setting in the .ini file to dial out any clipping from the default settings. A small bit of clipping is perfectly okay, but the devs claim the defaults settings, allow about 20-30% clipping. Not sure what wheel they tested that on, but on my CSW-V2, the default gain setting for the cars in the base installation allows a little too much clipping in the high-speed corners for my tastes. Not a big deal, very easy to dial out. And once you do, the cars will feel amazing. :)Second, the graphics. This was a big turn off for me the first time I tried AMS. Yes, I realize graphics aren’t the end-all-be-all measure for sim titles, but, coupled with what I thought at the time was poor FFB and a poorly designed GUI, the outdated looking graphics made me feel as though it wasn’t worth the time to negotiate the setup curve of the title. What I didn’t realize at the time was, AMS’ built-in graphics processing is terrible, but you don’t have to use it. By turning off almost every in-game graphic setting, and simply creating a profile in my GPU driver for AMS, and allowing the GPU to handle most of the processing, I was able to use the enhanced HDR setting in AMS, and it looks like a totally different game—very much comparable to any other modern title. When properly configured through the GPU, the outdated graphics gripe basically becomes a complete non-issue. Third, the GUI. Yes, it appears a bit cluttered and hard to navigate, but the more time I spend with the title, the more I seem to be discovering the method behind the madness. AMS remembers the little things, like which track you were driving in each particular car and what difficulty level you were using with that particular car/track combo. The latter was a welcome surprise, considering AI difficulty often varies by car/track combo. I believe some of these little conveniences that have been revealing themselves are made possible, in part, if not completely, by the way things are broken down and organized in the GUI. And, to be honest, after a few days of play, the GUI doesn’t seem nearly as chaotic as it did on day-one. :)So, as much as I’d like to say, “Please ignore my previous review.” I think reading them both is best, because there’s a good chance you’re going to be feeling some, if not all, of the things I felt about the game when I first tried it a few months ago. The thing to remember is, while all my past observations were indeed true, they only apply to the out-of-the box installation. With a little patience—a browse through the community forum and possibly a Google search or two—the initial installation can be transformed into a real racing pleasure that should appeal to just about any sim fan. Verdict: AMS is a definite must have for sim fans. Below is my original review. :o--------------------------------------------I heard a lot about this game and was excited about the track evolution aspect. After downloading it, and selecting the No Assist option, I then spent about 20 minutes trying to find out why it was still auto upshifting for me. After a Google search, I discovered that selecting manual wasn't enough (WTH??). There was a second setting for upshifting. Whatever, I moved on and started tackling the FFB. It felt promising, but when I went to start dialing it in, I realized there was no FFB meter (again... WTH?). I found a lot of information online, telling me to make manually adjustments in the config .ini files. That seemed a little archaic, and coupled with the lack of an FFB meter, I was just really turned off at this point. To make matters worse, the graphics are very, VERY dated looking, compared to just about any racing game made within the past 7 years. I have a GTX 1080 and had the settings cranked, viewing it on a 4K screen. It still looked dated. Even the onscreen HUD overlays looked like they were made for a kid's game. At the 1.5 hour mark, I just gave up an returned it. If I didn't already have three sims that I was thoroughly enjoying, I might have spent more time trying to massage AMS into shape. But there just seemed to be too much blind fiddling required. Verdict: Refunded.

												Don't often write recommendations but this is one of those times. Going to write it in order of 'Pros', 'Average', 'Cons'.PROS:-Physics are absolutely on point. (Cars like the V8 Super cars, Go-Karts, touring cars and F3), The levels of grip given to each wheel at certain times, and the way the car 'dances', like it should in lots of cases, it's completely unmatched by any other sim . EG, taking a corner, and the FR wheel hits a bump, you don't just feel it amazingly well in the FFB, the cars weight shifts extremely well, creating more lean on the LF tyre, the suspension then reacts to it, changing grip levels of both those tyres and the movement of the car. The list goes on and on about the reactions of the cars in different curcumstances.  You can also feel the effects of the downforce much more through the FFB and car control. Take the Formula 3, at high speed the car is much more planted, but at lower speed the wheel requires far more steering input as the downforce becomes almost non-existant and you are rellying on mechanical grip. Also, the suspension physics are immaculate, low speed reactions to bumps and kurbs is great. -Force Feed Back, Simply unmatched. No other sim is even close, 'Nuff said really. -Management... Yes, you have to manage tyre and brake temps. If you have the HUD on, you can see your brake and tyre temps in detail. Don't keep your tyres and brake temperatures up, they become less effective. -Car list, is fairly vast.... Go-Karts/X-cross/V8 Super cars/trucks/F3 etc etc Average:-Now one thing that got hyped, and rightly so, was the AI. The AI is great, far better than other titles I've played in Sim's. You can change their aggression, and skill level in percentage right up to %120. They'll do pretty well to hold their own on the track. But, and it's a big but, They also still hold big features that make you strongly remember they are AI. For example, AI does not have a clue what a blue flag is.... Imagine, you get out first in quallifying, get the tyres and brakes up to temp on that outlap, then full steam ahead down the Start/finish to start your flying lap. Just to be met with %50 of the AI coming out of the pitlane, and that don't react to blue flags.... It's such a simple thing that destroys the element of the AI supposedly being 'human'. Also when you change their aggression to 'extreme', they still are very cautious about passing you and defending. I lost my wing in F3, and completely removed myself from the racing line and slowed down to around 50mph, and moved right to the edge of the track, and there was still a queue of AI behind deciding on whether it's safe to pass me or not. Also, they don't defend as aggresive as this setting suggests, they often leave the door wide open. But the plus side in that is that they do try to counter attack..... Another note with the difficulty level, is it's too easy in some cases. I had the super Karts at Spielburg (I know I spelled that wrong), and I naturally have the dificulty set to %110. Within 17 minutes practice I was the quickest driver on track by .4 of a second... I reset the difficulty to %120, and within 45 minutes practice I was still the qiuckest driver by .3 of a second.  It should be a tad more difficult imo. 45 minutes practice, without ever driving that vehicle, should have me at the back of the pack somewhere...... BUT, In general race-craft, the AI is a huge improvement, and is actually fun and difficult to race against for the most part. CONS:-Graphics, it's not a huge dissapointment, but at some points it does feel very outdated. I'm running Maximum detail and it doesn't look right. I'm seeing jagged lines with Full detail and 16x AA. I feel i'm mising something, and the opponents cars give that old school floaty and pixelated look at 50+ meters. Maybe that's something at my end, but it's a bit of a turn off. Doesn't reflect the fun you have while driving though that's for sure. -Setting up the wheel. Now this is only if you are a perfectionist, like me. You may find yourself going back and forth changing the settings, but if you aren't new to sims and Race in the likes of iRacing, you may be more used to it. But it does seem to take a bit more effort. The con is only the time it takes, but it definitely returns reward when you dial the settings in. -Multiplayer. The public servers are a ghost town, everybody who has this Sim, and races online, races in a league no doubt. -Mods, I went searching for them on RaceDepartment. And there wasn't a huge amount. A lot of the tracks were made by 'Patrick', or something. And there are barely any quality tracks, the only quality tracks existing were the ones made by this 'Patrick'. One Gentleman said that this is down to the Devs not releasing info on the game to support modders making tracks, specifically the shaders. I don't know how much truth is in this, but it does go as a con in my book if it is truthful. Overall, if you're a heavy sim-enthusiast get it, just buy it. You are missing out on something amazing. But you should really look to get into a online league, because the Public MP servers are dead. Also, a league is just normally far more fun anyway than the public lobby bangers.

								For those on the fence because Automobilista uses what some describe as a dated physics and graphics engine, the answer is that does not matter at all. The team at Reiza UNDERSTAND what it takes to make a satisfying sim, and no amount of slick graphics (Project Cars) substitute for engaging driving and gameplay. Let's take the setup of the cars and the physics:Reiza has refined and tweaked the ISI engine so that almost every car available gives wonderful feedback to the driver. You can feel when you are on the edge, and this is down to not only the beautifully tweaked physics but very importantly the customisable sounds including tyres and various balance controls enables you to get a very good idea of how fast you can push. Every clue that you need, both in sound and feedback, is customisable and exceedingly well done, including rumble strips, grass and dirt, and for me this is the only sim which offers believable reactions to being offline or offtrack. It also makes it much easier than other sims to catch a slide because you can feel what is happening to the back end of the car.Frankly I do not care whether the graphics are not to PCars "standard". Most of those are in any case a distraction from the job in hand: racing. The cars are very well done and despite not being fleshed out with bling like PCars are still perfectly good and crucially are way ahead in practical driving terms.The force feedback is (again unlike Project Cars with its frankly ludicrously complex FF setup - which doesn't have any clear explanations as to what the absurd number of parameters mean) simple yet highly effective.The AI in Automobilista is outstanding and superior to ANY currently available racing sim, yet Reiza are still working to refine it. This makes it by far the most satisfying offline racing experience.The one slight misgiving is the available tracks. It's not because they are mostly Brazilian circuits or somewhat unfamiliar, but that many of them are rather plain looking and consist often of very wide tracks with long, shallow or sweeping curves. Some make like these but I find them a bit samey and lacking in character. However I think Reiza Studios recognise this and are encouraging third party circuits and perhaps in the future will offer some classic tracks.Overall this is a very promising sim and despite being early access is already close to being a very polished product. Even at this stage it is far more polished and playable than either PCars or Assetto. It is also far more polished and offers much better quality content than ISI whose own content in rfactor 2 is falling way behind.

								Automobilista is a pure racing sim and may not appeal to the "casual racing gamer" who has no racing wheel (which is not meant to be a bad thing at all). The sim is adressed to peaple with a FFB wheel and pedals which want to race cars at the limit.Contantwise, the game has its focus at the brasilian Stockcar series and features all of the series tracks. This means, the tracks are mostly unknown brasilian tracks, but there are also some very good internatioal tracks like Suzuka and Montreal. Besides the Stock cars, there is a large variety of racing cars like Formula One inspired (modern and historic), tintops and karts. The cars feel really good - some of the best FFB out there. The cars are challanging but predictable to drive, which offers a good challange.The AI is solid and fair. After rF2 propably the best.A great racing sim which offers out of the box the best experience in my opinion!

												My favorite racing sim hands down. Love it so much I bought it twice! I'm so happy to see Reiza Studios come so far from the days of Game Stock Car 2012. There's just so much to praise about this sim.+The sounds are great (though not Race Room Racing Experience good but still very excellent).+The car physics are well weighted so that every turn you make feels rights.+The force feedback is beautifully detailed so you feel every bump and slip the car makes. +The car selections are so incredibly varied that you can go from Karts to V10 Formula 1 and drive a Mini Cooper when you want a more managable vehicle. It's also the only sim with Stadium Super Trucks! STADIUM SUPER TRUCKS! Come on, what's not to love about that!? (Though they are quite tricky to drive at first, I suggest checking YouTube for assistance)+The track selection is also wonderfully varied and incredibly detailed. Lots of South American tracks that I had never heard of before and now can't get enough of with more European and American tracks to come!+The A.I., though not up to par with rFactor 2, is still a great challenge and competes well if not better than other racing sims.+The graphics are somewhat dated, however, if you follow the instructions in the manual to set up additional graphic settings, it'll be quite gorgeous.If you're looking for a recent, complete sim-racing package, look no further. This sim is easy to love once you've delved many hours into it.
